I found it by accident, buried in a folder labeled "Do Not Open Under Any Circumstances (Especially Not After 2 AM)." It wasn’t the username that gave it away—*surely* I would have remembered choosing something so aggressively millennial—but the password. A combination of my first dog’s name, a misplaced punctuation mark, and a year I can no longer remember being. 

Clicking it open felt like stepping into a time machine that had been left in the sun too long—everything warped, slightly sticky, and definitely not the version of me I thought I’d left behind. There were posts written in a voice I used to think was profound, and others that were just me trying to sound like I understood something I didn’t. 

I read a few entries. Then I closed it. Then I opened it again, just to check if I was still the same person who wrote them. I wasn’t. But I *had* been. And that, more than anything, felt like the kind of quiet, accidental nostalgia that sneaks up on you while you're trying not to think about how long it’s been.
